elements.content: The self-assembly of a zinc salt with the novel ligand 4,4′,4″-[(1,3,5-triazine-2,4,6-triyl)­tris­(sulfanediyl)]­tribenzoic acid generated 3D microporous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), namely, {[Zn4(L3–)2(O2–)­(H2O)2]·4EtOH} n . The frameworks with multiple Lewis basic sites exhibit easily sensitized properties. After encapsulation of the Tb3+ cation in this Zn-MOF, the as-obtained fluorescent-functionalized Tb@Zn-MOFs not only maintain distinguished chemical stabilities but also exhibit strong characteristic emissions of trivalent terbium ions. Interestingly, Tb@Zn-MOF has been chosen to be a potential highly selective and sensitive luminescent platform for the reversible detection of PO4 3– ions in aqueous and living cell buffer solutions with a fast response time of 10 s and a low detection limit (0.1 ppm). Strikingly, this work presents the first example of a fluorescent sensor that can quantitate PO4 3– in simulated biological fluids and monitor these ions in the water system in a wide range of concentrations from 10–6 to 10–3 M.
elements.clean_text: The self-assembly of a zinc salt with the novel ligand 4,4',4"-[(1,3,5-triazine-2,4,6-triyl)tris(sulfanediyl)]tribenzoic acid generated 3D microporous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), namely, {[Zn4(L3-)2(O2-)(H2O)2]⋅4EtOH} n . The frameworks with multiple Lewis basic sites exhibit easily sensitized properties. After encapsulation of the Tb3+ cation in this Zn-MOF, the as-obtained fluorescent-functionalized Tb@Zn-MOFs not only maintain distinguished chemical stabilities but also exhibit strong characteristic emissions of trivalent terbium ions. Interestingly, Tb@Zn-MOF has been chosen to be a potential highly selective and sensitive luminescent platform for the reversible detection of PO4 3- ions in aqueous and living cell buffer solutions with a fast response time of 10 s and a low detection limit (0.1 ppm). Strikingly, this work presents the first example of a fluorescent sensor that can quantitate PO4 3- in simulated biological fluids and monitor these ions in the water system in a wide range of concentrations from 10-6 to 10-3 M.

elements.content: The lanthanide-functionalized luminescent hybrid material Tb@Zn-MOF can be utilized as a potential highly selective and sensitive robust luminescent platform for the reversible detection of PO4 3− ions.
elements.clean_text: The lanthanide-functionalized luminescent hybrid material Tb@Zn-MOF can be utilized as a potential highly selective and sensitive robust luminescent platform for the reversible detection of PO4 3- ions.

elements.content: Currently, PO4 3– as a pollutant anion mainly exists in aquatic ecosystems, as well as in various industrial processes, which can cause water eutrophication and be harmful to human health. In addition, PO4 3–, including their derivatives, as the product of nucleoside polyphosphates (ATP, ADP, and AMP) in the human body, plays a vital role in the transduction, energy storage, and gene construction in biological systems. Therefore, studies on the effective detection of PO4 3– ions have attracted enormous attention. To date, various methods and techniques for the detection of anions have been reported, but many of them are unviewable, expensive, and unsuitable for portable on-site analyses. Among all detection technologies, fluorescence-based chemosensors have attracted much research interest because of their significant advantages such as rapid response, high sensibility, simplicity, portability, and ease of manipulation.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Currently, PO4 3- as a pollutant anion mainly exists in aquatic ecosystems, as well as in various industrial processes, which can cause water eutrophication and be harmful to human health. In addition, PO4 3-, including their derivatives, as the product of nucleoside polyphosphates (ATP, ADP, and AMP) in the human body, plays a vital role in the transduction, energy storage, and gene construction in biological systems. Therefore, studies on the effective detection of PO4 3- ions have attracted enormous attention. To date, various methods and techniques for the detection of anions have been reported, but many of them are unviewable, expensive, and unsuitable for portable on-site analyses. Among all detection technologies, fluorescence-based chemosensors have attracted much research interest because of their significant advantages such as rapid response, high sensibility, simplicity, portability, and ease of manipulation.

elements.content: Given that metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), a family of crystalline porous materials, can produce remarkable fluorescent signals with visible emission colors and be defined as a novel class of prospective chemical sensors. Currently, lanthanide-based MOFs (Ln-MOFs) have drawn great interest as fluorescent sensors compared to the transition-metal-based MOFs because of their unique optical properties such as high color purity, long fluorescence lifetime, large Stokes shift, and obvious emission spectra derived from the 4f–4f electron transitions via the “antenna effect”. To date, an alternative strategy to construct Ln-MOFs and optimize the photoluminescence has been reported and carried out by the incorporation of lanthanide ions into the MOFs via the postsynthetic method (PSM). Taking advantage of this unique method, the postsynthetic Ln-MOFs can be employed as ideal fluorescent probes.
elements.clean_text: Given that metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a family of crystalline porous materials, can produce remarkable fluorescent signals with visible emission colors and be defined as a novel class of prospective chemical sensors. Currently, lanthanide-based MOFs (Ln-MOFs) have drawn great interest as fluorescent sensors compared to the transition-metal-based MOFs because of their unique optical properties such as high color purity, long fluorescence lifetime, large Stokes shift, and obvious emission spectra derived from the 4f-4f electron transitions via the "antenna effect". To date, an alternative strategy to construct Ln-MOFs and optimize the photoluminescence has been reported and carried out by the incorporation of lanthanide ions into the MOFs via the postsynthetic method (PSM). Taking advantage of this unique method, the postsynthetic Ln-MOFs can be employed as ideal fluorescent probes.

elements.content: In fact, the majority of MOF-based sensors have been considered for the selective detection of phosphate radicals. However, the achievement of a fast response, sensing in living creatures, and reproducible performance for PO4 3– detection using fluorescence is still challenging. Stimulated by this challenge, as a continuation of research on fluorescent sensors based on Ln-MOFs, a novel lanthanide-doped MOF (Tb@Zn-MOF) was synthesized by encapsulating the Tb3+ ion into Zn-MOF ({[Zn4(L3–)2(O2–)­(H2O)2]·4EtOH} n , where H3L = 4,4′,4″-[(1,3,5-triazine-2,4,6-triyl)­tris­(sulfanediyl)]­tribenzoic acid) and exhibited easily sensitized properties, high chemical stabilities, and strong green luminescence. Furthermore, Tb@Zn-MOF is suitable for acting as a highly selective and sensitive robust luminescent platform that can reversibly detect PO4 3– in the aqueous and living cell buffer solutions with a fast response speed of 10 s and a low limit of detection (LOD) of 0.1 ppm. Strikingly, this work is the first example of a fluorescent sensor that can quantitate PO4 3– in simulated biological fluids and monitor these ions in the water system with a wide range of concentrations from 10–6 to 10–3 M.
elements.clean_text: In fact, the majority of MOF-based sensors have been considered for the selective detection of phosphate radicals. However, the achievement of a fast response, sensing in living creatures, and reproducible performance for PO4 3- detection using fluorescence is still challenging. Stimulated by this challenge, as a continuation of research on fluorescent sensors based on Ln-MOFs, a novel lanthanide-doped MOF (Tb@Zn-MOF) was synthesized by encapsulating the Tb3+ ion into Zn-MOF ({[Zn4(L3-)2(O2-)(H2O)2]⋅4EtOH} n , where H3L = 4,4',4"-[(1,3,5-triazine-2,4,6-triyl)tris(sulfanediyl)]tribenzoic acid) and exhibited easily sensitized properties, high chemical stabilities, and strong green luminescence. Furthermore, Tb@Zn-MOF is suitable for acting as a highly selective and sensitive robust luminescent platform that can reversibly detect PO4 3- in the aqueous and living cell buffer solutions with a fast response speed of 10 s and a low limit of detection (LOD) of 0.1 ppm. Strikingly, this work is the first example of a fluorescent sensor that can quantitate PO4 3- in simulated biological fluids and monitor these ions in the water system with a wide range of concentrations from 10-6 to 10-3 M.

elements.content: All reactants and reagents were obtained from a commercial company (Beijing HWRK) and used directly without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was performed using an EMPYREAN PANALYTICAL advanced diffractometer equipped with a diffracted-beam monochromator (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves were obtained with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a N2 atmosphere using a NETZSCH 449 C thermal analyzer. Photoluminescence spectra were obtained using an F-7000 FL spectrophotometer. Fourier transform infrared spectra were measured in the 4000–400 cm–1 region using a KBr pellet technique with a PerkinElmer spectrometer. The C, H, and N atoms were recorded on a PerkinElmer 2400 elemental analyzer. The pH was measured by a PHS-3C meter. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses of the crystals were performed using a Thermo Escalab 250 Xi spectrometer with a monochromatic Al Ka (hν = 1486.6 eV).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All reactants and reagents were obtained from a commercial company (Beijing HWRK) and used directly without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was performed using an EMPYREAN PANALYTICAL advanced diffractometer equipped with a diffracted-beam monochromator (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves were obtained with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a N2 atmosphere using a NETZSCH 449 C thermal analyzer. Photoluminescence spectra were obtained using an F-7000 FL spectrophotometer. Fourier transform infrared spectra were measured in the 4000-400 cm-1 region using a KBr pellet technique with a PerkinElmer spectrometer. The C, H, and N atoms were recorded on a PerkinElmer 2400 elemental analyzer. The pH was measured by a PHS-3C meter. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses of the crystals were performed using a Thermo Escalab 250 Xi spectrometer with a monochromatic Al Ka (hν = 1486.6 eV).

elements.content: The single-crystal data for Zn-MOF were collected using an Agilent Xcalibur E X-ray single-crystal diffractometer fitted with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The SADABS program was used for absorption corrections. The subsequent crystal structure of Zn-MOF was solved by direct methods, and the subsequent refinement proceeding was agented by full-matrix least-squares refinements based on F 2 with the SHELXTL-97 program. Furthermore, all H atoms were placed according to the different anisotropic parameters and least-squares fittings. After the final refinement, because of the indefinable and highly disordered solvent molecules, a few high-electron-density Q peaks were present in Zn-MOF. Hence, both the free solvent and disordered solvent molecules have been removed by using the PLATON SQUEEZE program. The detailed structure refinement and crystal data for Zn-MOF are given in Table S1. Selected bond lengths and angles are summarized in Table S2. Crystallographic data for the structures reported in this paper have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication CCDC 1553993.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The single-crystal data for Zn-MOF were collected using an Agilent Xcalibur E X-ray single-crystal diffractometer fitted with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The SADABS program was used for absorption corrections. The subsequent crystal structure of Zn-MOF was solved by direct methods, and the subsequent refinement proceeding was agented by full-matrix least-squares refinements based on F 2 with the SHELXTL-97 program. Furthermore, all H atoms were placed according to the different anisotropic parameters and least-squares fittings. After the final refinement, because of the indefinable and highly disordered solvent molecules, a few high-electron-density Q peaks were present in Zn-MOF. Hence, both the free solvent and disordered solvent molecules have been removed by using the PLATON SQUEEZE program. The detailed structure refinement and crystal data for Zn-MOF are given in Table S1. Selected bond lengths and angles are summarized in Table S2. Crystallographic data for the structures reported in this paper have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication CCDC 1553993.

elements.content: The yellow rodlike crystals of Zn-MOF were hydrothermally synthesized through a mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol), H3L (0.0263 g, 0.049 mmol), dimethylformamide (2.5 mL), ethyl alcohol (2.5 mL), water (1 mL), and Quadrol (20 μL), with 135 μL of nitric acid (2 M) used to adjust the pH of the solution. The mixtures were further sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave, heated at 70 °C for 72 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature. The collected product was washed three times with deionized water and dried at 60 °C in a vacuum. Yield: 66.25% based on metal. Elem anal. Calcd for Zn-MOF: C, 42.89; H, 3.31; N, 5.06. Found: C, 43.41; H, 3.169; N, 5.36.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Zn-MOF

The yellow rodlike crystals of Zn-MOF were hydrothermally synthesized through a mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.1 mmol), H3L (0.0263 g, 0.049 mmol), dimethylformamide (2.5 mL), ethyl alcohol (2.5 mL), water (1 mL), and Quadrol (20 μL), with 135 μL of nitric acid (2 M) used to adjust the pH of the solution. The mixtures were further sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave, heated at 70 °C for 72 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature. The collected product was washed three times with deionized water and dried at 60 °C in a vacuum. Yield: 66.25% based on metal. Elem anal. Calcd for Zn-MOF: C, 42.89; H, 3.31; N, 5.06. Found: C, 43.41; H, 3.169; N, 5.36.

elements.content: The Tb@Zn-MOF suspension was prepared by adding 30 mg of powdered compounds in a TbCl3·6H2O aqueous solution (40 mL, 2 mmol) after separation by centrifugation and washing with deionized water to remove residual Tb3+, and the collected crystal powders were dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 6.5 h. The freshly prepared samples were introduced into deionized water to form the suspension, and the pH was 6.5. The molar ratio of ZnII and TbIII ions was approximately 1:1, as proven by energy-dispersive spectrometry.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of the Tb@Zn-MOF Suspension

The Tb@Zn-MOF suspension was prepared by adding 30 mg of powdered compounds in a TbCl3⋅6H2O aqueous solution (40 mL, 2 mmol) after separation by centrifugation and washing with deionized water to remove residual Tb3+, and the collected crystal powders were dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 6.5 h. The freshly prepared samples were introduced into deionized water to form the suspension, and the pH was 6.5. The molar ratio of ZnII and TbIII ions was approximately 1:1, as proven by energy-dispersive spectrometry.

elements.content: For the anion-sensing experiments, 1 mL of the above suspension was instilled in an aqueous solution (1 × 10–3 M, 2 mL) containing different anions (anion = PO4 3–, F–, Cl–, Br–, I–. NO3 –, N3 –, SCN–, SO4 3–, CO3 2–, OAc–, H2PO4 –, and Cr2O7 2–). Then, the luminescence data of the suspensions were collected immediately.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Sensing Experiment

For the anion-sensing experiments, 1 mL of the above suspension was instilled in an aqueous solution (1 × 10-3 M, 2 mL) containing different anions (anion = PO4 3-, F-, Cl-, Br-, I-. NO3 -, N3 -, SCN-, SO4 3-, CO3 2-, OAc-, H2PO4 -, and Cr2O7 2-). Then, the luminescence data of the suspensions were collected immediately.

elements.content:
The structure and fluorescence stability of Tb@Zn-MOF in the aqueous solution with different pH values were investigated. After standing for 24 h, the suspension fluorescence spectra were measured.

Results and DiscussionCrystal Structure

The IR spectra of Zn-MOF were analyzed, as illustrated in Figure S1. A broad absorption peak appears between 3686 and 3060 cm–1 in the IR spectrum, corresponding to the stretching vibration of O–H in ethanol molecules. Because of the coordination interaction between the Zn2+ and carboxyl group, the absorption peak of the ligand (CO) at 1690 cm–1 blueshifts to 1609 cm–1. In addition, the absorption peaks at 1553 and 1460 cm–1 could be attributed to the stretching vibrations of the C–C and C–N bonds on the pyridine and benzene rings, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Investigation of the pH Stability of Tb@Zn-MOF

The structure and fluorescence stability of Tb@Zn-MOF in the aqueous solution with different pH values were investigated. After standing for 24 h, the suspension fluorescence spectra were measured.

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure

The IR spectra of Zn-MOF were analyzed, as illustrated in Figure S1. A broad absorption peak appears between 3686 and 3060 cm-1 in the IR spectrum, corresponding to the stretching vibration of O-H in ethanol molecules. Because of the coordination interaction between the Zn2+ and carboxyl group, the absorption peak of the ligand (CO) at 1690 cm-1 blueshifts to 1609 cm-1. In addition, the absorption peaks at 1553 and 1460 cm-1 could be attributed to the stretching vibrations of the C-C and C-N bonds on the pyridine and benzene rings, respectively.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that Zn-MOF crystallizes in an orthorhombic structure. Each asymmetric unit contains one crystallographically independent Zn2+ ion, half of a deprotonated L3– ligand, a quarter bridging O atom, and half of a bridging water molecule (a). As illustrated in b, the central Zn2+ ion is pentacoordinated, with one O atom derived from one bridging carboxyl of a disordered L3– ligand and two O atoms from two bridging carboxyls of the two L3– ligands and one bridging O atom of a water molecule and one coordinated water molecule. The triazine ring groups show a space occupation disorder and were modeled with two components. The disordered S2 atom was refined with two parts while constraining the sum of the occupancies to unity. The Zn–O bond lengths are in the range of 1.868(15)–1.996(4) Å within the normal range for this bond (Table S2). Meanwhile, the adjacent Zn2+ ions are interconnected through the carboxylate groups from the L3– ligand and a bridging O atom μ4-O derived from a water molecule, giving a tetranuclear [Zn4O­(COO)6] unit (b).
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that Zn-MOF crystallizes in an orthorhombic structure. Each asymmetric unit contains one crystallographically independent Zn2+ ion, half of a deprotonated L3- ligand, a quarter bridging O atom, and half of a bridging water molecule (a). As illustrated in b, the central Zn2+ ion is pentacoordinated, with one O atom derived from one bridging carboxyl of a disordered L3- ligand and two O atoms from two bridging carboxyls of the two L3- ligands and one bridging O atom of a water molecule and one coordinated water molecule. The triazine ring groups show a space occupation disorder and were modeled with two components. The disordered S2 atom was refined with two parts while constraining the sum of the occupancies to unity. The Zn-O bond lengths are in the range of 1.868(15)-1.996(4) Å within the normal range for this bond (Table S2). Meanwhile, the adjacent Zn2+ ions are interconnected through the carboxylate groups from the L3- ligand and a bridging O atom μ4-O derived from a water molecule, giving a tetranuclear [Zn4O(COO)6] unit (b).

elements.content: (a and b) Coordination environment and polyhedral representation of Zn2+ ions (H atoms are omitted for clarity). (c) Various coordination mode between Zn2+ and the ligand. (d) 2D-layered structure of Zn-MOF. (e) Stacking structure of Zn-MOF.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a and b) Coordination environment and polyhedral representation of Zn2+ ions (H atoms are omitted for clarity). (c) Various coordination mode between Zn2+ and the ligand. (d) 2D-layered structure of Zn-MOF. (e) Stacking structure of Zn-MOF.

elements.content: On the other hand, each cagelike [Zn4O­(COO)6] unit is connected by an L3– ligand and further forms doubly interlocked (4,4) layers (d). In addition, the neighboring layers further interdigitated to give a three-stacking structure along the b axis (e).
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, each cagelike [Zn4O(COO)6] unit is connected by an L3- ligand and further forms doubly interlocked (4,4) layers (d). In addition, the neighboring layers further interdigitated to give a three-stacking structure along the b axis (e).

elements.content: Upon excitation at 358 nm, the photoluminescence spectra of pristine Zn-MOF display a wide emission band at 408 nm (Figure S2), attributed to the π–π* electron transition of the ligand-to-metal charge transfer. After postsynthetic incorporation of Tb3+, the composites display a weak ligand-centered emission and bright-green luminescence, which can be easily visualized under UV irradiation (). The photoluminescence spectra of Tb@Zn-MOF exhibit characteristic emission peaks at 492, 546, 587, and 623 nm due to the f–f transitions of the Tb3+ ion, namely, 5D4–7F6, 5D4–7F5, 5D4–7F4, and 5D4–7F3 (Figure S3), which are attributed to the antenna effect that stems from energy transfer from the ligand to the Tb3+ ion. One unanticipated finding was that Zn-MOF is extremely easily sensitized by the Tb3+ ion, even at a low concentration of 10–8 M. Additionally, the sensitization process exhibits a fast response time of 10 s (Figure S4).
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties of Tb@Zn-MOF

Upon excitation at 358 nm, the photoluminescence spectra of pristine Zn-MOF display a wide emission band at 408 nm (Figure S2), attributed to the π-π* electron transition of the ligand-to-metal charge transfer. After postsynthetic incorporation of Tb3+, the composites display a weak ligand-centered emission and bright-green luminescence, which can be easily visualized under UV irradiation (). The photoluminescence spectra of Tb@Zn-MOF exhibit characteristic emission peaks at 492, 546, 587, and 623 nm due to the f-f transitions of the Tb3+ ion, namely, 5D4-7F6, 5D4-7F5, 5D4-7F4, and 5D4-7F3 (Figure S3), which are attributed to the antenna effect that stems from energy transfer from the ligand to the Tb3+ ion. One unanticipated finding was that Zn-MOF is extremely easily sensitized by the Tb3+ ion, even at a low concentration of 10-8 M. Additionally, the sensitization process exhibits a fast response time of 10 s (Figure S4).

elements.content: (a) Emission spectra of Tb@Zn-MOF with TbIII at 10–4, 10–5, 10–6, 10–7, and 0 mol/L (λex = 358 nm). (b) Corresponding CIE-1931 chromaticity diagram.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Emission spectra of Tb@Zn-MOF with TbIII at 10-4, 10-5, 10-6, 10-7, and 0 mol/L (λex = 358 nm). (b) Corresponding CIE-1931 chromaticity diagram.

elements.content: Considering practical applications, the thermal stability of Zn-MOF was first investigated. As illustrated in Figure S5, the weight loss of 11.2% can be observed in the range of 140–285 °C in the TGA curve, which proves that an ethanol solvent molecule is found freely in the structure unit (calcd 11.6%). Moreover, the framework of the compound was retained until 370 °C, revealing that Zn-MOF has a high thermal stability. Furthermore, the fluorescence and structure of Tb@Zn-MOF have exhibited prominent stability. At the same time, the fluorescence intensity of the crystal shows tiny changes despite its introduction into a base/acid aqueous solution for several days, with the pH ranging from 3 to 12 (Figure S6). Meanwhile, the composites can maintain their structural integrity not only in solutions under the pH value from 3 to 12 but also in a Na3PO4 aqueous solution, as confirmed by PXRD analysis (Figure S7).
elements.clean_text:
Stability of the As-Synthesized Compounds

Considering practical applications, the thermal stability of Zn-MOF was first investigated. As illustrated in Figure S5, the weight loss of 11.2% can be observed in the range of 140-285 °C in the TGA curve, which proves that an ethanol solvent molecule is found freely in the structure unit (calcd 11.6%). Moreover, the framework of the compound was retained until 370 °C, revealing that Zn-MOF has a high thermal stability. Furthermore, the fluorescence and structure of Tb@Zn-MOF have exhibited prominent stability. At the same time, the fluorescence intensity of the crystal shows tiny changes despite its introduction into a base/acid aqueous solution for several days, with the pH ranging from 3 to 12 (Figure S6). Meanwhile, the composites can maintain their structural integrity not only in solutions under the pH value from 3 to 12 but also in a Na3PO4 aqueous solution, as confirmed by PXRD analysis (Figure S7).

elements.content: In light of the structural stability and remarkable luminescence of Tb@Zn-MOF, a series of suspension-state luminescence experiments for the detection of anions were carried out. When the different anions were introduced into the suspension liquid of Tb@Zn-MOF, the luminescence of the Tb3+ emission was immediately and markedly influenced by the anions. We have noticed that a significant quenching in the fluorescence intensity with a fast response speed of 10 s can be observed after the addition of PO4 3– (Figure S4). In contrast, other anions have a slight influence on the luminescence intensity in identical test conditions, demonstrating that Tb@Zn-MOF could selectively recognize PO4 3– ions in aqueous media (a). Furthermore, the quenching effect leads to a change of the fluorescence color, and the phenomenon can be differentiated by the naked eye upon UV-light irradiation.
elements.clean_text:
Sensing of Inorganic Anions

In light of the structural stability and remarkable luminescence of Tb@Zn-MOF, a series of suspension-state luminescence experiments for the detection of anions were carried out. When the different anions were introduced into the suspension liquid of Tb@Zn-MOF, the luminescence of the Tb3+ emission was immediately and markedly influenced by the anions. We have noticed that a significant quenching in the fluorescence intensity with a fast response speed of 10 s can be observed after the addition of PO4 3- (Figure S4). In contrast, other anions have a slight influence on the luminescence intensity in identical test conditions, demonstrating that Tb@Zn-MOF could selectively recognize PO4 3- ions in aqueous media (a). Furthermore, the quenching effect leads to a change of the fluorescence color, and the phenomenon can be differentiated by the naked eye upon UV-light irradiation.

elements.content: (a) Relative fluorescent intensities of 5D0–7F2 at 545 nm for Tb@Zn-MOF dispersed in an aqueous solution containing various anions when excited at 358 nm. (b) Corresponding illustration under portable UV-light irradiation at 365 nm.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Relative fluorescent intensities of 5D0-7F2 at 545 nm for Tb@Zn-MOF dispersed in an aqueous solution containing various anions when excited at 358 nm. (b) Corresponding illustration under portable UV-light irradiation at 365 nm.

elements.content: Referring to the American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists, PO4 3– as a toxic anion can cause severe pollution in aquatic ecosystems and lead to high risks for human society. Hence, it is urgent to investigate the high-efficiency detection of PO4 3– ions, and further tests were performed to explore the sensitivity of the PO4 3– ion for sensing. With the PO4 3– ion gradually introduced into the suspension liquid, the luminescence intensities of the 5D4–7F5 transitions (545 nm) obviously weakened (a). The quenching effect of the suspension fluorescence was clearly observed in the 1.29 × 10–6 M (0.1 ppm) Na3PO4 solution, and the luminescence of the suspension entirely disappeared at a Na3PO4 concentration of 10–3 M. In b, the relative intensity (F 0/F) exhibits a good linear relationship at lower PO4 3– ion concentrations. Quantitatively, this fluorescent quenching effect can be calculated based on the Stern–Volmer (SV) equation: F 0/F = 1 + K SV[M], where F 0 is the fluorescent intensity of Tb@Zn-MOF before treatment by PO4 3–, F is the fluorescent intensity after the addition of the PO4 3– ion, K SV is the quenching coefficient of the anions, and [M] is molar concentration of the PO4 3– ion. The K SV value was calculated to be 4.07 × 103 L/mol, displaying the high quenching efficiency of the PO4 3– ion. When the PO4 3– concentrations are gradually increased, the SV plots show a nearly linear dependence with a correlation coefficient of 0.9942. As we have seen, this is the first time that fluorescent MOFs are used for quantitating the concentrations of PO4 3– in the aqueous solution, with a wide range of concentrations ranging from 10–6 to 10–3 M.
elements.clean_text: Referring to the American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists, PO4 3- as a toxic anion can cause severe pollution in aquatic ecosystems and lead to high risks for human society. Hence, it is urgent to investigate the high-efficiency detection of PO4 3- ions, and further tests were performed to explore the sensitivity of the PO4 3- ion for sensing. With the PO4 3- ion gradually introduced into the suspension liquid, the luminescence intensities of the 5D4-7F5 transitions (545 nm) obviously weakened (a). The quenching effect of the suspension fluorescence was clearly observed in the 1.29 × 10-6 M (0.1 ppm) Na3PO4 solution, and the luminescence of the suspension entirely disappeared at a Na3PO4 concentration of 10-3 M. In b, the relative intensity (F 0/F) exhibits a good linear relationship at lower PO4 3- ion concentrations. Quantitatively, this fluorescent quenching effect can be calculated based on the Stern-Volmer (SV) equation: F 0/F = 1 + K SV[M], where F 0 is the fluorescent intensity of Tb@Zn-MOF before treatment by PO4 3-, F is the fluorescent intensity after the addition of the PO4 3- ion, K SV is the quenching coefficient of the anions, and [M] is molar concentration of the PO4 3- ion. The K SV value was calculated to be 4.07 × 103 L/mol, displaying the high quenching efficiency of the PO4 3- ion. When the PO4 3- concentrations are gradually increased, the SV plots show a nearly linear dependence with a correlation coefficient of 0.9942. As we have seen, this is the first time that fluorescent MOFs are used for quantitating the concentrations of PO4 3- in the aqueous solution, with a wide range of concentrations ranging from 10-6 to 10-3 M.

elements.content: (a and c) Luminescence spectra of Tb@Zn-MOF under different concentrations of PO4 3– aqueous solutions and in living organisms. (b and d) Plot of the K SV curve between the luminescence intensity and PO4 3– concentration in an aqueous solution and living organisms.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a and c) Luminescence spectra of Tb@Zn-MOF under different concentrations of PO4 3- aqueous solutions and in living organisms. (b and d) Plot of the K SV curve between the luminescence intensity and PO4 3- concentration in an aqueous solution and living organisms.

elements.content: With regard to the luminescence signal response of PO4 3– ions in living organisms, a series of simulated physiological conditions were well established and prepared by a 0.02 M 4-(2-hydroxyethyl)-1-piperazineethanesulfonic acid aqueous solution and by adjusting the pH to 7 to simulate the living cell buffer solution. The relevant sensitivity experiment was performed under identical experimental conditions, and the PO4 3– solution was added at the same time. As illustrated in a, the fluorescence characteristic intensity of the 5D4–7F5 transitions (545 nm) was quenched distinctly with the PO4 3– content in the solution from 10–6 to 10–3 M. The dependence of quenching on the fluorescence intensity is obvious under the concentration at 2.49 × 10–6 mol/L (0.2 ppm). When the mixed solution concentration of PO4 3– reaches 0.001 mol/L, the fluorescence is quenched completely. Likewise, the K SV value can be quantified as 3.69 × 104 L/mol by the SV equation using the same method, and the linear correlation coefficient (R) in the K SV curve of composites toward PO4 3– is 0.99688 at low concentrations, revealing a significant quenching effect on the Tb@Zn-MOF fluorescence.
elements.clean_text: With regard to the luminescence signal response of PO4 3- ions in living organisms, a series of simulated physiological conditions were well established and prepared by a 0.02 M 4-(2-hydroxyethyl)-1-piperazineethanesulfonic acid aqueous solution and by adjusting the pH to 7 to simulate the living cell buffer solution. The relevant sensitivity experiment was performed under identical experimental conditions, and the PO4 3- solution was added at the same time. As illustrated in a, the fluorescence characteristic intensity of the 5D4-7F5 transitions (545 nm) was quenched distinctly with the PO4 3- content in the solution from 10-6 to 10-3 M. The dependence of quenching on the fluorescence intensity is obvious under the concentration at 2.49 × 10-6 mol/L (0.2 ppm). When the mixed solution concentration of PO4 3- reaches 0.001 mol/L, the fluorescence is quenched completely. Likewise, the K SV value can be quantified as 3.69 × 104 L/mol by the SV equation using the same method, and the linear correlation coefficient (R) in the K SV curve of composites toward PO4 3- is 0.99688 at low concentrations, revealing a significant quenching effect on the Tb@Zn-MOF fluorescence.

elements.content: Usually, wastewater or pollutants include more than one kind of anion, and it is therefore imperative to check the PO4 3– ion selectively on Tb@Zn-MOF in the presence of other anions (F–, Cl–, Br–, I–, NO3 –, N3 –, SCN–, SO4 3–, CO3 2–, OAc–, H2PO4 –, and Cr2O7 2–). The resulting solutions containing other anions and PO4 3– were implemented by luminescence measurements. As illustrated in Figure S8, the obvious fluorescence–quenching effect of Tb@Zn-MOF toward PO4 3– was not significantly affected by the addition of other anions, proving that Tb@Zn-MOF can act as a remarkable selectivity chemosensor for the detection of PO4 3– among the above anions.
elements.clean_text: Usually, wastewater or pollutants include more than one kind of anion, and it is therefore imperative to check the PO4 3- ion selectively on Tb@Zn-MOF in the presence of other anions (F-, Cl-, Br-, I-, NO3 -, N3 -, SCN-, SO4 3-, CO3 2-, OAc-, H2PO4 -, and Cr2O7 2-). The resulting solutions containing other anions and PO4 3- were implemented by luminescence measurements. As illustrated in Figure S8, the obvious fluorescence-quenching effect of Tb@Zn-MOF toward PO4 3- was not significantly affected by the addition of other anions, proving that Tb@Zn-MOF can act as a remarkable selectivity chemosensor for the detection of PO4 3- among the above anions.

elements.content: As is well-known, fluorescent sensors are usually expensive and hard to reuse, restricting their practical applications. Hence, simple regeneration and fast response are the key parameters for assessing a probe. For the purpose of exploring the performance of regenerated Tb@Zn-MOF, the probe was immersed in a 10–3 M aqueous solution of PO4 3– for 5 min to completely form PO4 3–/Tb@Zn-MOF. The resulting suspension was centrifuged and washed with water several times. After five recycling processes, the PXRD and fluorescence intensity of the recyclable probe were identical with those of the original Tb@Zn-MOF ( and S5), suggesting that Tb@Zn-MOF can be utilized as a remarkable and recyclable fluorescence detector for the detection of PO4 3–, which demonstrates promising practical applications.
elements.clean_text:
Recyclable Luminescence Experiments

As is well-known, fluorescent sensors are usually expensive and hard to reuse, restricting their practical applications. Hence, simple regeneration and fast response are the key parameters for assessing a probe. For the purpose of exploring the performance of regenerated Tb@Zn-MOF, the probe was immersed in a 10-3 M aqueous solution of PO4 3- for 5 min to completely form PO4 3-/Tb@Zn-MOF. The resulting suspension was centrifuged and washed with water several times. After five recycling processes, the PXRD and fluorescence intensity of the recyclable probe were identical with those of the original Tb@Zn-MOF ( and S5), suggesting that Tb@Zn-MOF can be utilized as a remarkable and recyclable fluorescence detector for the detection of PO4 3-, which demonstrates promising practical applications.

elements.content: (a) Fluorescence intensity changes during sensing and recycling of Tb@Zn-MOFs. (b) Photograph with UV irradiation showing the emission intensity changes during sensing and recycling of Tb@Zn-MOF.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Fluorescence intensity changes during sensing and recycling of Tb@Zn-MOFs. (b) Photograph with UV irradiation showing the emission intensity changes during sensing and recycling of Tb@Zn-MOF.

elements.content: Further studies were performed for the purpose of investigating the remarkable sensitization of this Zn-MOF toward Tb3+. In Figure S7, the PXRD pattern of the original is similar to that of the posttreatment composite, suggesting that the structures of the frameworks are unchanged. As demonstrated in Figure S9, the UV–vis absorption bands of Tb@Zn-MOF show a significant red shift from 289 to 305 nm after posttreatment by Tb3+, showing that the mechanism of fluorescence sensitization can be speculated to be due to the interaction between Tb3+ and the Lewis basic sites in Zn-MOF. To justify the above speculation, XPS has been utilized for revealing the coordination interaction. As shown in the summary of the XPS spectra (a), after treatment by Tb3+, two new peaks at 1242 and 1277 eV appeared, by which the existence of Tb3+ in the composites can be ascertained. Meanwhile, it can be found that the peaks at 399.23 eV in the N1s XPS spectrum from free triazinyl N atoms have a significant red shift to 399.60 eV (b), suggesting that there is a coordination interaction between Tb3+ and the triazinyl Lewis base sites (N) in Zn-MOF. In addition, the binding energy of S2p does not change (c), implying that the S atom from the free thioether bond may not be involved in the coordination interaction with Tb3+. Hence, after the posttreatment, the product emits a distinctive green luminescence that can be attributed to the N atom from free triazinyl nitrogen coordinating with Tb3+, which can significantly increase energy transfer from the L3– ligand to the trivalent Tb centers, resulting in a characteristic emission of the Tb3+ ions.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanism of Luminescent Response

Further studies were performed for the purpose of investigating the remarkable sensitization of this Zn-MOF toward Tb3+. In Figure S7, the PXRD pattern of the original is similar to that of the posttreatment composite, suggesting that the structures of the frameworks are unchanged. As demonstrated in Figure S9, the UV-vis absorption bands of Tb@Zn-MOF show a significant red shift from 289 to 305 nm after posttreatment by Tb3+, showing that the mechanism of fluorescence sensitization can be speculated to be due to the interaction between Tb3+ and the Lewis basic sites in Zn-MOF. To justify the above speculation, XPS has been utilized for revealing the coordination interaction. As shown in the summary of the XPS spectra (a), after treatment by Tb3+, two new peaks at 1242 and 1277 eV appeared, by which the existence of Tb3+ in the composites can be ascertained. Meanwhile, it can be found that the peaks at 399.23 eV in the N1s XPS spectrum from free triazinyl N atoms have a significant red shift to 399.60 eV (b), suggesting that there is a coordination interaction between Tb3+ and the triazinyl Lewis base sites (N) in Zn-MOF. In addition, the binding energy of S2p does not change (c), implying that the S atom from the free thioether bond may not be involved in the coordination interaction with Tb3+. Hence, after the posttreatment, the product emits a distinctive green luminescence that can be attributed to the N atom from free triazinyl nitrogen coordinating with Tb3+, which can significantly increase energy transfer from the L3- ligand to the trivalent Tb centers, resulting in a characteristic emission of the Tb3+ ions.

elements.content: XPS spectra of as-prepared Zn-MOF, Tb@Zn-MOF, and PO4 3–/Tb@Zn-MOF: (a) survey spectrum; spectra of (b) N1s, (c) S2p, and (d) Tb3d.
elements.clean_text: 6  XPS spectra of as-prepared Zn-MOF, Tb@Zn-MOF, and PO4 3-/Tb@Zn-MOF: (a) survey spectrum; spectra of (b) N1s, (c) S2p, and (d) Tb3d.

elements.content: Generally, it has been exploratory that the effect of ions on the luminescence quenching of Ln-MOFs is due to four sources: (1) coordination between the organic ligands and ions; (2) collapse of the framework structure; (3) interaction between the ions and lanthanide metal ion in the MOF; (4) excitation or emission spectra of the compounds overlapped by the UV–vis absorption spectra of the ions. Herein, the mechanism of such a fluorescent signal response of PO4 3– has been further explored. After treatment with PO4 3–, the original framework and crystallinity of Tb@Zn-MOF are still retained, as shown in the PXRD patterns (Figure S7); meanwhile, there is a decrease, to a certain extent (Δτ = 0.429 ms), of the luminescence lifetime by the coalescence of PO4 3– in composites (Figures S10 and S11). However, the excitation and emission spectra of Tb@Zn-MOF are not overlapped by the UV–vis absorption peak of the anions (Figure S12). Considering another mechanism, the remarkable fluorescence quenching by the PO4 3– ions, it can be suggested that the Tb3+ ion in Tb@Zn-MOF weakly interacts with the PO4 3– ion. To verify this hypothesis, further XPS analysis was carried out. a displays the survey XPS spectra of Tb@Zn-MOF/PO4 3–. It can be found that six elements, namely, Tb, Zn, O, C, S, and P, are present in the product. The peaks at 1278.3 and 1243.5 eV in d could be assigned to Tb 3d3/2 and 3d5/2, originating from Tb3+. In d, after treatment with PO4 3–, the Tb 3d5/2 spectrum was further blueshifted to 1242.4 eV, which can be put down to the electrostatic interaction between Tb3+ and PO4 3–. The above analysis demonstrates that energy transfer from the ligand to the trivalent terbium ion becomes weak, which is caused by a weak coordination between PO4 3– and Tb3+ in Tb@Zn-MOF.
elements.clean_text: Generally, it has been exploratory that the effect of ions on the luminescence quenching of Ln-MOFs is due to four sources: (1) coordination between the organic ligands and ions; (2) collapse of the framework structure; (3) interaction between the ions and lanthanide metal ion in the MOF; (4) excitation or emission spectra of the compounds overlapped by the UV-vis absorption spectra of the ions. Herein, the mechanism of such a fluorescent signal response of PO4 3- has been further explored. After treatment with PO4 3-, the original framework and crystallinity of Tb@Zn-MOF are still retained, as shown in the PXRD patterns (Figure S7); meanwhile, there is a decrease, to a certain extent (Δτ = 0.429 ms), of the luminescence lifetime by the coalescence of PO4 3- in composites (Figures S10 and S11). However, the excitation and emission spectra of Tb@Zn-MOF are not overlapped by the UV-vis absorption peak of the anions (Figure S12). Considering another mechanism, the remarkable fluorescence quenching by the PO4 3- ions, it can be suggested that the Tb3+ ion in Tb@Zn-MOF weakly interacts with the PO4 3- ion. To verify this hypothesis, further XPS analysis was carried out. a displays the survey XPS spectra of Tb@Zn-MOF/PO4 3-. It can be found that six elements, namely, Tb, Zn, O, C, S, and P, are present in the product. The peaks at 1278.3 and 1243.5 eV in d could be assigned to Tb 3d3/2 and 3d5/2, originating from Tb3+. In d, after treatment with PO4 3-, the Tb 3d5/2 spectrum was further blueshifted to 1242.4 eV, which can be put down to the electrostatic interaction between Tb3+ and PO4 3-. The above analysis demonstrates that energy transfer from the ligand to the trivalent terbium ion becomes weak, which is caused by a weak coordination between PO4 3- and Tb3+ in Tb@Zn-MOF.

elements.content: In conclusion, we developed a lanthanide-functionalized fluorescent hybrid material, Tb@Zn-MOF, derived from Zn-MOF via the PSM. The as-obtained luminescent-functionalized Tb@Zn-MOF not only maintained excellent chemical stability but also exhibited the characteristic emission of Tb3+. Interestingly, it is obvious that Tb@Zn-MOF could be utilized as a highly selective and sensitive robust luminescent platform for the reversible detection of PO4 3– in an aqueous environment, showing a response time of 10 s and a low LOD of 0.1 ppm. This provides a novel technique for the recognition of inorganic anions, which is extremely significant in both physiological and ecological environments.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, we developed a lanthanide-functionalized fluorescent hybrid material, Tb@Zn-MOF, derived from Zn-MOF via the PSM. The as-obtained luminescent-functionalized Tb@Zn-MOF not only maintained excellent chemical stability but also exhibited the characteristic emission of Tb3+. Interestingly, it is obvious that Tb@Zn-MOF could be utilized as a highly selective and sensitive robust luminescent platform for the reversible detection of PO4 3- in an aqueous environment, showing a response time of 10 s and a low LOD of 0.1 ppm. This provides a novel technique for the recognition of inorganic anions, which is extremely significant in both physiological and ecological environments.

cln_elements.content: The yellow rodlike crystals of Zn-MOF were hydrothermally synthesized through a mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol), H3L (0.0263 g, 0.049 mmol), dimethylformamide (2.5 mL), ethyl alcohol (2.5 mL), water (1 mL), and Quadrol (20 μL), with 135 μL of nitric acid (2 M) used to adjust the pH of the solution. The mixtures were further sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave, heated at 70 °C for 72 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature. The collected product was washed three times with deionized water and dried at 60 °C in a vacuum. Yield: 66.25% based on metal. Elem anal. Calcd for Zn-MOF: C, 42.89; H, 3.31; N, 5.06. Found: C, 43.41; H, 3.169; N, 5.36.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Zn-MOF

The yellow rodlike crystals of Zn-MOF were hydrothermally synthesized through a mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.1 mmol), H3L (0.0263 g, 0.049 mmol), dimethylformamide (2.5 mL), ethyl alcohol (2.5 mL), water (1 mL), and Quadrol (20 μL), with 135 μL of nitric acid (2 M) used to adjust the pH of the solution. The mixtures were further sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave, heated at 70 °C for 72 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature. The collected product was washed three times with deionized water and dried at 60 °C in a vacuum. Yield: 66.25% based on metal. Elem anal. Calcd for Zn-MOF: C, 42.89; H, 3.31; N, 5.06. Found: C, 43.41; H, 3.169; N, 5.36.

cln_elements.content:
Upon excitation at 358 nm, the photoluminescence spectra of pristine Zn-MOF display a wide emission band at 408 nm (Figure S2), attributed to the π–π* electron transition of the ligand-to-metal charge transfer. After postsynthetic incorporation of Tb3+, the composites display a weak ligand-centered emission and bright-green luminescence, which can be easily visualized under UV irradiation (). The photoluminescence spectra of Tb@Zn-MOF exhibit characteristic emission peaks at 492, 546, 587, and 623 nm due to the f–f transitions of the Tb3+ ion, namely, 5D4–7F6, 5D4–7F5, 5D4–7F4, and 5D4–7F3 (Figure S3), which are attributed to the antenna effect that stems from energy transfer from the ligand to the Tb3+ ion. One unanticipated finding was that Zn-MOF is extremely easily sensitized by the Tb3+ ion, even at a low concentration of 10–8 M. Additionally, the sensitization process exhibits a fast response time of 10 s (Figure S4).

Stability of the As-Synthesized Compounds

Considering practical applications, the thermal stability of Zn-MOF was first investigated. As illustrated in Figure S5, the weight loss of 11.2% can be observed in the range of 140–285 °C in the TGA curve, which proves that an ethanol solvent molecule is found freely in the structure unit (calcd 11.6%). Moreover, the framework of the compound was retained until 370 °C, revealing that Zn-MOF has a high thermal stability. Furthermore, the fluorescence and structure of Tb@Zn-MOF have exhibited prominent stability. At the same time, the fluorescence intensity of the crystal shows tiny changes despite its introduction into a base/acid aqueous solution for several days, with the pH ranging from 3 to 12 (Figure S6). Meanwhile, the composites can maintain their structural integrity not only in solutions under the pH value from 3 to 12 but also in a Na3PO4 aqueous solution, as confirmed by PXRD analysis (Figure S7).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties of Tb@Zn-MOF

Upon excitation at 358 nm, the photoluminescence spectra of pristine Zn-MOF display a wide emission band at 408 nm (Figure S2), attributed to the π-π* electron transition of the ligand-to-metal charge transfer. After postsynthetic incorporation of Tb3+, the composites display a weak ligand-centered emission and bright-green luminescence, which can be easily visualized under UV irradiation (). The photoluminescence spectra of Tb@Zn-MOF exhibit characteristic emission peaks at 492, 546, 587, and 623 nm due to the f-f transitions of the Tb3+ ion, namely, 5D4-7F6, 5D4-7F5, 5D4-7F4, and 5D4-7F3 (Figure S3), which are attributed to the antenna effect that stems from energy transfer from the ligand to the Tb3+ ion. One unanticipated finding was that Zn-MOF is extremely easily sensitized by the Tb3+ ion, even at a low concentration of 10-8 M. Additionally, the sensitization process exhibits a fast response time of 10 s (Figure S4).

Stability of the As-Synthesized Compounds

Considering practical applications, the thermal stability of Zn-MOF was first investigated. As illustrated in Figure S5, the weight loss of 11.2% can be observed in the range of 140-285 °C in the TGA curve, which proves that an ethanol solvent molecule is found freely in the structure unit (calcd 11.6%). Moreover, the framework of the compound was retained until 370 °C, revealing that Zn-MOF has a high thermal stability. Furthermore, the fluorescence and structure of Tb@Zn-MOF have exhibited prominent stability. At the same time, the fluorescence intensity of the crystal shows tiny changes despite its introduction into a base/acid aqueous solution for several days, with the pH ranging from 3 to 12 (Figure S6). Meanwhile, the composites can maintain their structural integrity not only in solutions under the pH value from 3 to 12 but also in a Na3PO4 aqueous solution, as confirmed by PXRD analysis (Figure S7).

metadata.title:
Postsynthetic Metalation Metal–Organic Framework
as a Fluorescent Probe for the Ultrasensitive and Reversible Detection
of PO4
3– Ions
